awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Designing Nitrogen Coordinated Single Atomic Metal Electrocatalysts for Selective CO2 Reduction to CO
awd_abstract_narration:
Fossil fuels (i.e., coal, petroleum, and natural gas) are still today's primary energy sources, but their utilization increases carbon emissions.  Technologies that can convert waste carbon dioxide (CO2) into value-added chemicals have great economic and societal importance for realizing a sustainable energy future.  Electricity, generated from sunlight, offers a potential sustainable route for CO2 conversion to chemicals, but present electrochemical approaches require expensive precious metals as catalysts. The project will focus on discovery of cost-effective alternatives to the precious metal catalysts while contributing to U.S. research leadership in energy utilization.   The project will impact a broad range of technology related to renewable energy, water usage, transportation, and defense. Moreover, the research results will be incorporated into curriculum development, student mentoring, and educational outreach to high-school teachers and students. This award will also broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in conducting research and will positively impact higher education in science and engineering disciplines.

Nitrogen coordinated single atomic metal (e.g. iron, cobalt, or nickel) is a new type of electrocatalyst that has demonstrated impressive activity and relatively high selectivity for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to carbon monoxide (CO) in recent research.  However, the chemical nature of the active sites as well as the catalytic mechanisms for CO2 reduction in such complex catalyst systems are not fully understood. In addition, the factors controlling selectivity to CO2 reduction versus the competitive water reduction reaction are not well known. This research aims to provide fundamental understanding of rationally designed nitrogen coordinated single atomic metal sites embedded in a carbon framework and to elucidate the relationship between the synthesis, properties and performance of the catalysts in selective CO2 reduction into CO. The research team will 1) predict the active sites using first-principles calculation methods, 2) synthesize the catalysts containing the predicted active sites and local carbon structures, 3) conduct comprehensive characterization of the chemical properties, structure, and morphology of the synthesized catalysts, and 4) measure the performance of the synthesized catalysts for electrochemical CO2 reduction. This research will provide insights on how to achieve the highest possible activity and selectivity of the catalysts for CO2 reduction to CO through tuning the coordination environment of the central metal-nitrogen atom and the local carbon structure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Electrochemical conversion of CO2 to value-added chemicals and fuels is a desirable pathway to mitigate CO2-emission and pursue carbon neutrality due to its feasible anthropogenic manipulation and energy sustainability using renewable electricity. CO2 reduction reactions (CO2RR) can be tuned to produce various products, such as CO, C2H4, or C2H5OH, through designing catalysts and controlling the micro-environment of reaction interfaces during electrocatalysis. Although CO2 recycling via electrochemical CO2RR is attractive, it requires stable operation at industrial-level energy efficiencies (EEs, e.g., > 50%) and current densities (e.g., > 200 mA cm–2).

In this project, we focus on catalyst development for CO2-to-CO conversion, primarily due to its high technological readiness and economic feasibility for promising industrial implementation soon. CO, an energetic molecule, is regarded as an intermediate that can be mixed with H2 as syngas to synthesize high-value hydrocarbons through Fischer-Tropsch (F-T) reactions. Notably, the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 at the cathode is often coupled with the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode, which can generate CO/H2 and O2, respectively. As byproducts of the CO2 to CO conversion, applying H2 and O2 to a fuel cell can generate electricity, an effective decarbonization technology. However, the electrochemical reduction of CO2 to CO still faces significant challenges, lacking highly efficient, low-cost, and durable catalysts to achieve sufficient current density and Faradaric efficiency (FE) simultaneously for desirable industry applications.

Based on previous efforts, we have identified the carbon-supported, nitrogen-coordinated, and atomically dispersed metal sites are the most promising catalysts for CO2-to-CO conversion due to their high activity, selectivity, and earth abundance. In this project, we explore the new class of atomic metal site catalysts in terms of their synthesis, characterization, catalytic improvement, and fundamental understanding of active sites and reaction mechanisms. We also expand our research effort from traditional single-metal sites to dual-metal sites, aiming to overcome current challenges and create new catalyst formations. Importantly engineering single metal site catalysts in the form of MN4 using an effective nitrogen-doped carbon model was extensively developed to exclusively study the effect of carbon particle sizes, metal content, and M-N bond structures on catalytic activity and selectivity. The structure-property correlation was deeply analyzed by combining the experimental results with the theoretical calculations to uncover the CO2RR performance evolution mechanisms. During the project, among studied single metal site catalysts, Fe sites are active at relatively positive potentials, while less selective to CO at low potentials for generating industrial-level current density. On the contrary, single Ni sites are less active at high potential but more selective at low potential. However, an ideal catalyst for the CO2RR should generate high jCO at low potentials while maintaining high CO selectivity, i.e., high FECO. Therefore, an effective solution is to integrate both types of single metal sites to yield high jCO and FECO in a wide potential range for CO2 to CO conversion.

Incorporating a second metal (M2) to form direct M1-M2 bonds in M-N-C catalysts could fundamentally modify metal sites' electronic and geometric structures, offering significant room to improve catalytic performance toward the CO2 to CO conversion. In this project, the dual metal sites, perfectly inheriting the advantage of single metal sites, are extensively explored in terms of effective synthesis approaches, accurate structural and chemical characterization, theoretical modeling, and performance improvements for the CO2RR. We have designed effective Fe-Ni dual metal site catalysts, which could break the scaling relationship limitation by offering additional sites to alter the surface adsorption to CO2 and reaction intermediates. Moreover, CO2 reduction in flow reactors was designed in this project to demonstrate the effectiveness of the newly developed dual metal sites catalyst to achieve industry-level current density and energy efficiency for the CO2 to CO conversion. Importantly, we provide insights into the electrolyzer design for CO2 electrolysis.

The primary outcome of this project is to provide a comprehensive understanding of designing and engineering highly efficient and durable atomic metal site-based M-N-C catalysts for CO2 to CO conversion. This effort leverages our substantial expertise in developing atomically dispersed metal site catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in the past decade. The research outcome could inspire innovative catalyst design and synthesis to build new active site structures and address current challenges associated with linear scaling relationship limitations and activity-stability trade-offs during the CO2 to CO conversion.

Overall, this project was very successful and productive, which partially trained three Ph.D. and three undergraduate students in the past five years. The obtained understanding and knowledge were also immediately documented in recent research and review articles published in prestigious journals, including Angew Chem, Advanced Materials, Energy Environmental Science. The acquired understanding of designing atomic metal sites catalysts also directly benefits catalyst development for other relevant applications of clean energy, such as fuel cells, water electrolyzers, and ammonia electrosynthesis, which generated many high-profile papers in Nature Energy, Nature Catalysis, JACS, and Angew Chem.


Last Modified: 12/02/2023
Modified by: Gang Wu
